in South Korea is a
prominent fall-winter event that attracts millions of
participants.  This year, the activity
returned on January 6 despite
concerns about climate change and
global warming.
Mayor Hoa Tron said that
unexpected rain before the festival had caused the
ice on the lake to have no temperature.  As
usual, the ice is about 30 cm thick every year, but
this year it is only about 23
cm. Global warming is making it
difficult for us to
organize the festival. We have taken
preparations and are fortunate.  There are still many
tourists who come to join the
festival to experience hand-fishing through
holes cut in the surface of a
large frozen river to catch
San Neo salmon, a species of mountain trout that only
lives in  The freshwater area is very clean. They
can also ski, ice skate, play
soccer and other fun activities.
Last time it was so cold. I cried but this
time I'm laughing and there will be a
hearty barbecue dinner at the party.  Officials said
